column1: Conversation
split?

Can someone help me understand how is an average tasting pizza company worth so much with stock up 220%+ in 5 years? Are there significant growth tailwinds ahead? Food/restaurant seems very cut throat and their product seems average at best.It does like they price down their foods and hence compete on being value meals? Also, seems like they are very invested in tech and own their delivery infrastructure so cost advantages? Overall, seems like they have realized efficiencies in their costs, digital transformation, keeping prices low and have a strong brand and leadership team?But, it still beats me that it’s still very average pizza at best and the company’s product isn’t the best out there. I guess their strategy and positioning is based on ‘cheap pricing, strong branding, cost efficiencies’ since you can’t really create that much of a ‘difference’ in pizzas :-). Beats me why they are performing better than a lot of tech, Fintech and good solid companies?Thoughts on this and if this is worth buying for the long term?

Looking at the last Q report the thing that stands out to me is they spent over $1 billion buying back stock. What is disturbing to me about it is they used debt to do it. Their costs are exploding across the board and next year will be far worse. I am in the food business and by Jan 1st we will have raised prices 10% across the board in 6 months. Not only that, shipping costs are also exploding with no end in sight. I've been in the food business for over 35 years and I've never seen pricing pressure and shortages like this. The question is, why is the company buying expensive stock and using debt to do it? This is not an Domino's problem only and it will affect everyone in the business. IMO, restaurant stocks arefacing a tsunami of raising costs in 2022 and their share prices do not reflect that reality.
I'm not missing out in this dip.
pizza places using UberEATS, doordash and GrubHub are stealing dominos market share and also their labor pool.Up down, whatever but without huge labor changes in 5 years or less this company is toast
